body_html:
Apparently, that number is not arbitrary according to this comment in this SO post:

A sparse tensor is defined through its nonzero values (in TensorFlow, but also in about any algebra package that defines sparse structures). A matrix or tensor is said to be sparse if most of its elements are zero, and so this representation is much more economical (although operating with it is generally more complex).

body:
Apparently, that number is not arbitrary according to this comment in this SO [post](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/39838234/sparse-matrix-from-a-dense-one-tensorflow/41676814?noredirect=1#comment83489373_41676814):

> A sparse tensor is defined through its nonzero values (in TensorFlow, but also in about any algebra package that defines sparse structures). A matrix or tensor is said to be sparse if most of its elements are zero, and so this representation is much more economical (although operating with it is generally more complex).
